"Based on a true story." I never know what to expect when I read those words on a movie poster, especially when it is a high profile story where I already know the end result in the real world. I knew the general idea of what happened in Captain Phillips' ordeal with the pirates, so I wondered if they would be able to still pull off the tension of an attack at sea. Sure enough I was riveted. While you may know 1 or 2 key things that happen in the story, there are lots of little moments that should keep you on the edge of your seat. One of the more interesting aspects of the film is that, despite the title, it is not all focused on that one guy. We see a lot of events where Captain Phillips is merely the MacGuffin which brings a number of other characters together. This is initially set up in the opening scenes when, right after showing Phillips leaving for his trip, we are shown the pirates gathering their crew for the day. There are similar scenes later when the navy is gearing up to become involved in the situation. So, while we have a clear protagonist this isn't solely his movie, and the film doesn't go out of its way to artificially inflate him into some super action hero. In fact it almost gives the movie a documentary feel, which is also felt in the over use of handheld shaky camera. I really hated the shaky look of the film in the early scenes, but later I felt like things became more stable and I didn't need any more dramamine.

Tom Hanks should have received a best actor nomination, it's as simple as that. His accent was spot on, and he held it perfectly for most of the film. He seems so level-headed throughout the film, but as events continue to escalate around him, you can sense an underlying emotional roller coaster. This all culminates to the final scenes which I won't spoil for others, but I can say left me in tears. On the flip side I don't think Barkhad Abdi deserved a nomination for supporting actor. His performance did not contain much nuance, in fact it was somewhat flat and one-note. I felt like they were trying to prod me into feeling a bit sympathetic for his character because he was caught between a rock and a hard place, but I never was convinced and Abdi's performance lacked the underlying heart to get me there. The rest of the pirate crew (the only other significant characters in the film) were all typical movie bad guys. You've got your one young kid who's in over his head, and just kind of wants to go home. You've got your almost silent guy who's just trying to do his job without asking too many questions. And finally you've got your big muscle-bound guy who has rage issues, and creates a bunch of artificial tension simply by questioning his cohort who's supposed to be the one in charge. If you've seen any other movie or TV show with a hostage situation you'll probably recognize these personalities.

That is my biggest problem with Captain Phillips as a film. While it has the unique aspect of being a true story, it feels so carbon copy out of Hollywood Hostage Stories 101. Through no fault of their own I just kept thinking "I've seen this before." Now that's not a huge problem, because it is a quality story, but I just wanted more surprises. The opening had so much promise, because the battle with the pirate ship and the subsequent confrontation between the pirates and the crew were great. Yet eventually it became a hostage story, and I started losing interest. It doesn't help that the second half of this film really dragged. It was almost a constant cycle of yelling and bickering between the pirates, threatening to kill a hostage, and then agreeing that a dead hostage is worthless. Eventually things picked up, though, and the closing scenes were excellent and did a great job of recapturing that tension I felt in the beginning of the film. Perhaps if they had condensed things a bit and edited out some of the middle scenes it would have been even better, but I'm not sure if the final moments would have the same impact if the ordeal didn't feel so long. Either way, even with the lull that hit in the middle, I still found this to be a very good film. I won't be revisiting it any time soon, but I'm glad I was able to see one of the better movies from 2013.

Captain Phillips manages to deliver a great movie with some of Tom Hanks best acting coupled with some fantastic set pieces. It tells the tale of the first US cargo ship to be captured in over 200 years and it's based on a true story. Starting off with mentions has to be the plot; now while in my personal opinion it was well paced, I never felt the level of tension I feel the film wanted to create. They weren't terrorists with military weapons like normal action movies; they were just 4 men with 2 AK's. Because of this and the fact that (spoiler) no civilians are hurt for the movie, I feel as if the opportunity was wasted. Now the thing is, in a movie review like this, I can't make too much criticisms like that as its based on a true story and its not like they can change the story tot he way I like it or would have preferred. This was an experience that a human being actually went through and I can't even believe how traumatizing it must have been. For that, the actor that was picked had to deliver a riveting performance so as to replicate what he actually went through; and ladies and gentlemen, Tom Hanks delivers. He's no action hero; or a person with a specific set of skills; he's just a normal guy who was driving a boat to deliver some supplies. The movie does a really great way of showing this by introducing you to his wife in the beginning and the fact that they're having trouble with their kids; it humanizes him in a way and throughout the movie, Phillips spends most of his time with a gun in his face, scared. He's  not stupid, mind you, which is shown in his attempts to help his crew while on the ship. The main relationship that is focused on is that of Phillips and Muse, the Somali captain. Abdi does a great job of portraying a fisherman/pirate and as they spend time together in the movie, Phillips begins to understand his character and its at its peak in the final act with a powerful scene. Speaking of which, the somalis' mostly didn't speak english and while this may have been a turn off for some, I thought it was a good idea as it helped to further show that they were foreign; of different worlds. Phillips, from america where anything is possible, and Muse, from Somali where he's pressured to get money and trapped in a life he can't get out of. It's the small conversations that showcase the profound simplicity of these characters, such as when Muse tells him that he always wanted to go to America and buy a car. As stated before, I felt like the tension wasn't what it could have been, but the final act was strong, with tense action scenes and great music. While the focus was on the relationship, I felt no connection for the other characters; I suppose this is because it was mainly Phillips' story that was being told. The cinematography must also be praised with glorious shots of the sea in its beauty along with the the sheer differences in size of the Navy and the somalian fisherman boat. It's as if it was a metaphor for how America is the dominant super-power and has all the resources while Somali is currently suffering based on the event of the movie. Paul Greengrass directs this magnificent, tense drama about a sea captain taken hostage by Somali pirates. based on a true story this is a real white knuckle ride as the action switches from the huge container ship Maersk Alabama as it is initially attacked by a small band of pirates, to the confines of the lifeboat in which the Somalis hold the ship's captain hostage. It is very effectively done and the final few scenes provide such a realistic portrayal of how such an ordeal affects an individual that I found it deeply upsetting. Tom Hanks takes the lead and this fine actor gives another masterclass in screen acting. He is simply brilliant as are his co-stars, especially the pirates, high on adrenaline and khat, who give a palpable depiction of their desperation. The scenes are well directed and the cramped and sweaty spaces of the ship corridors and lifeboat are well used to produce feelings of intense claustrophobia and panic. This movie was very good and very intense.  It holds your attention and never lets go.  Director Paul Greengrass is great in the way he treated the story with a very straightforward, matter-of-fact approach (similar to how he did United 93) and with great attention to detail and technical accuracy.

The acting was great, aside from Tom Hanks's weird accent at the beginning (that seems to go away by the middle of the movie).  I really liked Tom Hanks's steady and clear-minded portrayal of Richard Phillips.  Phillips seemed to have a clear head, knew what he was doing, and was at least somewhat prepared for the threat.  I know a ton of accolades have been heaped on Barkhad Abdi's role as pirate leader Abduwali Muse, but while Abdi did fine, I barely noticed his performance in the movie, and I don't understand what all the hype is about.

I liked that the movie gave us a proper introduction to the pirates and the world they came from, almost making them sympathetic to a degree (though ultimately, I don't care how bad it is where you're from; there's no excuse for piracy).

The climax was very intense, and the effect was enhanced by the way the music built up to a crescendo and then went quiet in the immediate aftermath of the killing of the pirates, leaving the lifeboat silent except for whatever noise the lone surviving occupant - Phillips - was making.

I know it's been talked about to death already, but the ending scene where a shocked Phillips receives treatment from a Navy corpsman was really well-done.  It was unique in terms of how honest the portrayal of someone in shock was.  That said, there's a lot more to the movie than this one scene and I get annoyed when it's the only scene anyone will talk about.

I was pretty frustrated at how the crew of the ship didn't have guns, or any other projectile weapons they could've used to defend themselves or stop the pirates from boarding in the first place.  Also, one question that I had was, can the USA actually arrest, try, and imprison a foreign national, especially for a crime committed in international waters?

Fantástica producción del director Paul Greengrass (Bourne Supremacy, Bourne Ultimatum, The Green Zone) que logra construir una película que desde que carbura, y lo hace bastante pronto de haber iniciado, no apaga el ritmo y mantiene al expectador tenso y emocionado al mismo tiempo. Basada en los hechos reales sobre la captura del Capitán Richard Phillips por piratas somalíes en el 2009. La elección de Tom Hanks en el papel principal es acertada y éste logra presentar con credibilidad y dramatismo un personaje que no busca ser un héroe, que no trata de impresionar a nadie, solo desea navegar en el mar, ser un buen capitán y sobretodo... sobrevivir. El resto del elenco no son conocidos y creo que más de uno, son sus primeros papeles, pero que eso no lo engañe, cada actor del elenco, en ambos lados del conflicto cumplen con sus roles y apoyan efectivamente a Tom Hanks. Un filme que logra sacar jugo a la tremenda fotografía que los cines aportan ahora presentando escenas impresionantes en sus enfoques. Genial uso de la música instrumental que se vuelve un aliado del director Greengrass para llevar al máximo el impacto de esta película que como antes comenté, no deja descansar al expectador y hace que uno viva cada escena, casi como si estuviera allí. La historia permite apreciar el peligroso trabajo que llevan a cabo los marinos mercantes cuando sus rutas los llevan a aguas demasiado cercanas a sectores controlados por piratas modernos, que lo más impresionante es ver que no ocupan grandes buques o grandes masas de hombres para poner en jaque a las embarcaciones comerciales, una simple lancha de motor con 4 sujetos armados basta para crear una crisis donde vidas están en peligro. Altamente recomendada.

It must be hard not to like Tom Hanks. He's always seemed like such a jovial, fun-loving person, the kind of guy you can have a few drinks with at a party and just laugh and laugh at his stories and anecdotes.

And, lest we forget, the man is one hell of an actor.

I don't know Tom Hanks. I've never spent any time with him, nor have I ever even met him personally. Therefore, I can't verify anything in my first paragraph above. These are just impressions I get from the guy, and from these impressions, I'm making guesses. It's all just speculation.

But there's no speculation involved in the sentence directly preceding the above paragraph. That is a cold, hard fact. I don't need to go through the man's filmography to illustrate this, but if you're looking for recent proof, just rent "Captain Phillips." You'll get all the proof you need...and maybe then you'll understand my shock that the guy was somehow snubbed of a Best Actor nomination this year.

The funny thing is that, as much as "Captain Phillips" is a showcase for Hanks' ability as an actor, it's also quite easy to forget you're watching a performance (or even a movie, at times). Despite his star power, I often forgot I was watching Tom Hanks. He simply BECAME Captain Richard Phillips of New Jersey. The movie sometimes takes on a documentary-like feel. That's how effective both Hanks and the film really are. Like fellow Best Picture nominee "Gravity," "Captain Phillips" is a masterful example of a prolonged exercise in tension.

As the film opens, Captain Richard Phillips (Hanks) is piloting the container ship MV Maersk Alabama to Mombasa, Kenya. This is a perilous venture because the route is going to take the ship past the coast of Somalia, a hotspot for pirate activity. Sure enough, the ship is attacked and eventually boarded by a small band of Somali pirates, led by Muse (Barkhad Abdi). They plan on ransoming the ship and crew for millions of dollars in insurance money from the shipping company.

This is a recent story, so there's a good chance most audience members will be familiar with how this plays out. But that does nothing to diminish the white-knuckled tension permeating throughout the movie. Captain Phillips does his best to placate his pirate aggressors, but they're like a powder keg waiting to go off; one wrong move, and everybody dies. And although they're clearly destitute, they're certainly not simpletons, especially their leader, Muse. He's intelligent, calculating, and--perhaps most dangerous of all--determined.

Director Paul Greengrass utlizes the same gritty, shaky-cam technique of his previous efforts (including "United 93," "The Bourne Ultimatum," and the underrated "Green Zone") and the effect is intoxicating and claustrophobic, and I mean that as a compliment. There are times when we feel like we're right there with Phillips and his captors.

Hanks' performance is about as real and raw as you can get, but I must also praise Somali newcomer Barkhad Abdi as the pirate leader. It's always risky to cast newcomers or non-actors in major roles opposite big name stars (e.g., Clint Eastwood's "Gran Torino"), but Abdi goes toe-to-toe with Hanks, even managing to garner some sympathy for the desperate Muse. We get the sense that he is not an evil man; he's simply playing the hand he was dealt. The movie doesn't make excuses for his actions, but it does dare the audience to think about what they would do if they were in his shoes.

"Captain Phillips" is the kind of film that leaves you gasping and feeling wrung-out. It's merciless and unrelenting, but the efforts of Hanks, Abdi and Greengrass make it an extraordinary film. You should definitely check it out.

While "Captain Phillips" engages with some compelling questions with regards to power and economics, it's tough to feel that it ever engages with them to the degree that it might. The whole thing is still fundamentally an action movie, with the white man framed as protagonist and the black man as antagonist, and, while it's certainly more complicated than that, the bulk of the movie is spent on the action, and the audience with which I saw it seemed content to cheer on the Navy and even to laugh in spots at the mishaps of the Somali pirates. I think "Captain Phillips" is trying to do something good, and I even think it accomplishes its worthy goals to a large degree, and I'm certainly not going to complain about Greengrass' choice to eschew sentimentality (at least until the final few minutes) in favor of a more objective, procedural approach, but I'm left with the feeling that we're never provided enough context. Not enough context for the action to be coherent, in certain cases, too much context, in a way, for the suspense to be suspenseful (knowing going in that Phillips escapes relatively unharmed really deflates the dramatic sails), not enough context for me to really connect with any of the characters beyond the most superficial level, and not enough context for the larger issues it's tackling to really mean much.

Probably not the "complex portrait of the myriad effects of globalization" that it claims to be; as a thinkpiece, Captain Phillips has an intriguing foil in Barkhad Abdi's lead pirate and not a whole lot else. But as a gray-shaded thriller, Captain Phillips delivers, particularly in the second half when clunky exposition is thrown to the wayside. Hanks is obviously great but Abdi is the true star of the show, sympathetic while never sinking anywhere near some "pirate with a heart of gold" cliche. This film can be amazing at times but is also riddled with problems.  The movie gets the plot going rather quickly, basically within 20 minutes.  After that, the film becomes amazingly engrossing for the next 45 minutes or so.  There was a period of like 30 minutes where I legitimately couldn't turn away.  The film was that entertaining.  But it's also way too long.  This would've been a phenomenal 90 minute film.  But after Phillips gets kidnapped, the film starts to go downhill.  The excellent pacing and tense atmosphere found in the film's first half basically disappear.  The film quickly becomes repetitive: the kidnappers threaten Phillips, he begs them not to hurt him, and finds some way to convince them to not hurt him; he then continues to find ways to undermine them.  Splice in some shots of people negotiating with the kidnappers and the SEALs readying their weapons on the Navy destroyer, rinse and repeat.  The film just keeps showing the same stuff over and over again for the last 45 minutes, and it really almost kills the film.  It certainly makes it drag, and having been, well, enraptured by the first half, I find myself losing interest and becoming bored.  This could've been an amazing film...instead it was basically reduced to mediocrity by awful editing and poor pacing.

	Captain Phillips is a tediously long, drawn out, anti-action, illogical, impractical bore.
	Paul Greengrass might have been successful employing his hand-held, unsteady cam technical approach in United 93.  But that technique here makes the film come across as a shaky, rocky and distracting (from the tension of the character based drama) failure.  Captain Phillips is not Cloverfield.  Plus it takes place on a freighter - not  in a canoe.  
	Another thing  -  the completely wasted and trite 2 minute opening sequence.  Where Captain Richard Phillips leaves his home accompanied by his wife (Kathleen Keener, forgettable) for the sole reason of "grounding" an engaging, concerning, serious moment where they discuss the security and safey of his job.  Greengrass should have just cut this cardboard, poorly written, ineffective bit. Cut.  It. Out. Leave it on the editing floor.  Along with the rest of the movie.
	Another thing - the Somali pirates.  There were no subtitles.   Don't think it was the version I watched.  But .... what the hell were they talking about?  What the hell were they saying?  Physical and emotional reactions are one thing.  Yet when you can't understand the language, you technically have a HARDER time getting into their characters.  Which honest I did much at all.    I would completely understand if they didn't have subtitles during the moments when the Somalians were taking the ship hostage.  Such lack of subtitles could have been successful in invoking a feeling of the shipmates inability of understanding  what was being said.  Which would have installed a definite sense of tension and fearfulness.  Yet at the beginning when the pirate captain (Barkhad Abdi, who looked too similar to most of the other Somalian pirates/actors in the film which made him loose a deeper sense of identity)  was choosing his other band mates, I felt I could not connect to the importance nor the intensity of the scene.
	Another thing - the implausibility of the whole hostage take over.  So a ship carrying cargo through treacherous international waters not auto-guarded by the UN to third world war inflicted countries doesn't have guns?  Of any short?  Besides flare missels?  Really?  REALLY?  Mathematically speaking, the MV Maersk Alabama had a crew of what?  Twelve? Sixteen? Even more?  Against a band of 4 or 5 pirates?  Huh?  Yes the pirates did have automatic machine guns.  But like Captain Phillips speechified before they were boarded: "Remember that you know the ship.  They don't." So a macho-men crew of 12+ on their own "home turf"  couldn't take The Expendables gutsy action to devise a plan to fight back?  Sigourney Weaver done it.  Jodi Foster has done it.  Angelia Jolie even.  But shipmen can't?   Really?  REALLY?  Sure.  Fine.  Whatever.  To me I just find it implausible and completely unbelievable.

From the previews Tom Hank's attempt at an accent even turned me off (in the movie it's completely inconsistent.  And still annoying).  His acting and embodiment of Richard Phillips - except for a handful of scenes - is that of a fearful, timid man.  And at times gutless. Is it strange that I found A Hijacking to feel a little more real than this film, even though the former isn't based on a true story and the latter is.  A Hijacking, if you're unaware, is a film detailing a similar situation to this film except it also looks at the emotional stress of those handling the hostage negotiation, on top of the duress the crew goes through during their ordeal.  It is an excellent film, but a quietly intense one at that.  If you're stuck between watching this or A Hijacking and you're looking for a film heavy on "action" and suspense, then this film is the way to go.  But if you love films, you'll go out of your way to watch both.  The thing about A Hijacking is the fact that it focuses more on the negotiations between the pirates and the company that owns the ship.  There's a lot of going back and forth between them, so the film is very dialogue heavy, and some of the most important scenes in the film, such as the hijacking itself, are done off-screen.  So the film subverts expectations for this genre of film, it's a little more understated and, therefore, a little more realistic.  Not to take anything away from this film, and I don't doubt anything that happened in this film, but I also found it to be like a heavily dramatized account of the real life story.  And that's understandable, particularly if you want a wide audience to invest in your story, you exaggerate things a little bit more for the dramatic effect.  Again, I don't doubt that this was a horrific thing that happened to the people on the ship and, later, to Captain Phillips after he's taken hostage on the lifeboat, but the film is a little bit more dramatically manipulative than it probably wants to let on.  That doesn't mean that the dramatic freedoms they took made the film worse.  In actuality, I think that's why part of the film is as good as it is.  Paul Greengrass knows how to direct intense and suspenseful movies, and this film is no different.  He's got the same cinema-verite style that makes it feel like you're almost part of the crew stuck in the same situation, I think the uncertainty of the situation translates incredibly thanks to its cinematography and camerawork.  With that said, while I complain about the film not feeling like an accurate representation of what happened, that doesn't mean that the style in which the film was presented is bad, or anything of the sort.  Again, for what Paul Greengrass is trying to present, it works perfectly.  It's just strange finding a film, that's inspired by real-life events but not actually based on one, feel more realistic than a film that IS based on a real-life situation.  That doesn't speak, at all, to the quality of each individual film.  It's just an observation.  But moving on, I did find that the movie, after the pirates take captain Phillips hostage on the lifeboat, slows down...almost to a complete halt.  Almost as slow as the lifeboat they were in on, like they were just trying to kill time before the climax came.  Not that I can blame them for that, you need to pace yourself before the big climax...that's more than understandable.  You need the lows in order to appreciate the highs even more.  If the film had been a constant high, then you'd have been numbed by it all by the end of the film.  But I still think that they could've shortened these parts up a bit in order to make the film tighter and more concise.  Regardless of its length, I still found this film to be an easy watch, but there's still some stuff that could've been cut out that wasn't needed.  With that said, the actual climax of the film itself, with the Navy Seals trying to secure the targets in the lifeboat, was outstanding and probably the main reason the film gets the rating it did.  Greengrass has this way of just getting the most out of these situations.  If it takes him 20 minutes to get where he needs to go, then so be it, but he's doing it for a reason.  He's doing it in order to create tension, suspense, and the uncertainty that something may happen that could fuck all this up, even if you know of the real life case.  So props to Greengrass and the crew for doing this like true pros.  Tom Hanks is outstanding, but what else do you expect from him.  He's strong and commanding, yet incredibly vulnerable at the same time.  He doesn't know if he's gonna make it out alive out of this situation, so the fact that he manages to stay so calm in this situation rather than breaking out in hysterics is a testament to Hanks' strengths as an actor.  I liked the story as well as it, in a more understated manner, highlights the problem that globalization has on the economy of some of these third-world countries.  Not that the film paints a favorable portrait of the pirates, which it doesn't, but it does give a potential reason for why they've decided to become pirates.  So the film is much more than just the hijacking.  If you can, seek out both this and A Hijacking because they're equally as different but for completely different reasons.

Films that are based on true events are hit or miss - sometimes they are accused of taking artistic liberties to overdramatize aspects of the story, and other times they fall victim to trying to stay so close to what really happened that they become more of a documentary than intended. 'Captain Phillips' toes this line exceptionally well, as the Paul Greengrass film is powerful, attention-grabbing and believable. The film takes a look at the events of April 2009 when the cargo ship Maersk Alabama was seized by Somali pirates off the horn of Africa and its captain, Richard Phillips, was taken hostage and subsequently rescued by SEAL Team Six. The event lends itself to being depicted in an exciting manner on film, and Greengrass does not squander this opportunity. The cinematography feels real. Gritty. Harrowing. The music, aided by a score from Henry Jackman, successfully conveys the tone and gravity of the events that transpired. And then there's the acting. It's hard to believe Tom Hanks was not rewarded for his portrayal of Phillips with an Academy Award nomination, especially considering his performance in the final moments of the film. Additionally it's worth recognizing the jobs done by the actors who played the Somali pirates, including Barkhard Abdi, who was in fact rewarded with an Academy Award nomination for best supporting actor. The setting of the high seas was another element that brought 'Captain Phillips' to life, as there really is nowhere to run, and less places to hide. Regardless of whether everything in 'Captain Phillips' is depicted how these events actually happened in reality, it is one of the most interesting, exciting films of 2013.

(4 Stars) Captain Phillips is a very good dramatic thriller that knows how to bide its time without ever boring the audience. It doesn't follow action movie rules and makes every moment feel real, making it seem authentic rather than a Hollywood-ized version of the actual event. This is helped with believable acting headed by Tom Hanks (who got snubbed at the Oscars this year) and a great job of humanizing the Somalian pirate Muse (Barkhad Abdi). He could have been a Die Hard-on-a-boat villain, but there's reason to why he does what he does.

I compare it most to Zero Dark Thirty, where it's not really an action movie, but a dramatic film with action elements. And the last few scenes exhibit some of the best acting of Tom Hanks's career. Captain Phillips is an emotional thriller that takes you from the beginning.

Paul Greengrass certainly has a forte. He does these character driven action-biopics masterfully without making you feel like he's recycling a successful formula each time. In the world of modern Hollywood where so many directors think you have to jump a train of a ramp into a fighter jet carrying a nuclear weapon set to destroy the White House, Greengrass's subdued, nuanced approach to creating tension is extremely refreshing. The motivations of characters in Greengrass's films are never black and white. Captain Phillips manages to take a story that everyone already knows and make it intense and unpredictable. You'll find as you watch the movie that you don't know as many details as you think you did about this incredible incident. It is masterfully acted and directed. The script is sparse and feels very natural. Its such a rare combination to find a film that combines directing, acting, and writing to create the depth of character found in this movie. Tom Hanks gives a wonderful performance the last 10 minutes of which will leave you wondering why he wasn't an Oscar nominee.

"Am I in my cabin dreaming, or are you really scheming to take my ship away from me? You'd better think about it; I just can't live without it, so please don't take my ship from me!" Now that I've released the Grand Funk Railroad that always gets stuck in my head whenever I see films about the overthrowing of a ship captain, for those of you who kind of want "Saving Mr. Banks" to actually relate to "Saving Private Ryan", don't worry, because in 2013, Captain John Miller really is back to war, and this time, he takes to the sea against... pirates. I'm sorry, but in this day and age, I find it kind of amusingly awkward to call modern pirates "pirates", although it's not like we can call them terrorists, not just because that's not necessarily what they are, but because when you hear about a Paul Greengrass film about a terrorist highjacking, you can't help but think of "United 93 II: We're Gonna Need a Bigger Boat". Hey, I'd rather they call it that as opposed to "Crimson Tide II", because I don't want people to start thinking about how bad stuff always seems to happen to ships named after my beloved Alabama. Well, maybe people will just think that bad stuff always happens to any kind of craft when it's commanded by Tom Hanks. Oh, Houston, we most certainly have a problem indeed, but, it sure does make for a good film, although, make no mistake, there actually are some problems here.

Its storytelling assurance limited, the film often conforms to near-Hollywoodistically manipulative structural conventions as a heroic action thriller, hitting plenty of tropes, but limiting conventions by limiting depth to the flesh-out of potentially formulaic characters. That being the case, I suppose you could say that underdevelopment things a sense of genericism, but more than that it thins a sense of human impact, which is there, sure, yet undercut by little placement of attention into the protagonists and antagonists who we are trapped with in a tense, ostensibly character-driven thriller. It's ultimately hard to not feel as though you know little about the well-portrayed, but undercooked characters behind a well-told but dramatically filed down narrative that still takes its time to drag along with repetitious, if not aimless meditations upon tension building through anything from exhausting action set pieces to meandering thoughtful moments. The film ultimately outstays its welcome, essentially compensating for excessiveness with predominant effectiveness, yet either bloating or meandering, while placing only so much attention on characterization, resulting in a coldness to storytelling which is made all the more distancing by inconsistencies in tonal intensity. While storytelling meanders, extended periods of subtle tension are never less than adequately intriguing, until broken by many a spell of quiet dryness which loses tension and stiffens pacing, blanding things up, if not dulling things down, and consistently allowing you to meditate upon the structural shortcomings by marking highlights in misfires in ambition. Perhaps director Paul Greengrass tries a touch too hard to mold a meditative, if still rather Hollywood thriller, yet as much as I complain, inspiration matches ambition enough for the strengths of the film to be considerable, while flaws rarely prove to be as considerable as I make them sound, resulting in a consistently compelling effort, but one whose potential is too betrayed by Hollywood conventions, underdevelopment and inconsistencies in pacing for the final product to stand as strong as I was hoping, much less as strong as many are saying. I wish the film could have hit harder, but make no bones about it, it still hits pretty hard, with plenty of inspiration behind the handling of a worthy story concept.

I suppose the wealth of depth was always to be limited by the sheer minimalism to the subject matter of this claustrophobic dramatic thriller, but the subject matter is still rich with potential for layered intensity that is brought to life by highlights in scripting by Billy Ray that may be undercooked and overblown, but is generally controlled enough in its thoughtful storytelling and set piece drawing to do a serviceable job of fleshing out intensity. Yeah, the selling of depth and tension could be more than simply serviceable, but Ray's script has enough sharpness to its clever dialogue and tightness to its narrative structuring to make up for limitations in depth enough to endear, though not as much as the directorial execution of Ray's script. Paul Greengrass' direction is itself flawed, with sometimes unsubtly conventional, if not blandly dry atmospherics, but it's generally very effective, with stylish plays on Henry Jackman's brooding score work, thumping sound design and realistic handheld camera filming that immerse you into bitingly well-staged action sequences, enhanced by a fair degree of thoughtfulness to the more human aspects. The underdevelopment of the human aspects defuse much of the dramatic impact which could have driven the final product a long way, but Greengrass does what he can with only so much, and ultimately grips with smartly stylish intensity, while the performers round out the value of compellingness to this character-driven dramatic thriller. Material is, of course, thinner than many are saying, though just about everyone delivers as best he can, whether he be among the threatened crew members whose portrayers project a relatable nervousness, or among the Somalian antagonists whose portrayers project an unnerving harshness, particularly the chilling primary antagonist Barkhad Abdi. Of course, the man who really powers this film is leading man Tom Hanks, who, to tell you the truth, remains held back by limitations in material, being initially not allowed to do anything beyond project a distinguished charisma that sells the collectiveness and stature of a worthy captain in a situation that calls for a strong leader, but really engrossing when the plot thickens and the conflict grows weightier, for Hanks effortlessly nails the dramatic range that encompasses anguish and heroic intensity through powerful dramatic layering. Hanks ranks among the most important actors in modern film, maybe of all time, and he hasn't been given the material to firmly remind of this lately, with even this performance truly shining in moments that arrive too late for Hanks to be considered all-out great on the whole, but when Hanks gets his chance, he cuts deep with one of the better performances of 2013, which isn't to say that there's ever a point where Hanks does anything less than utilize effortlessly assured charisma to carry this thriller, which, when backed by inspiration within Greengrass as an offscreen lead, perseveres through its limitations and achieves, maybe not the strength I was hoping for, but rewarding strength nonetheless.

Bottom line, Hollywood action thriller conventions and little attention to characterization distance depth, while an excessive length and some dulling atmospheric dry spells really shake the impact of the final product, which is still kept from being shaken all that much by the worthy story concept, decent script, solidly intense direction and strong acting - especially by leading man Tom Hanks - that make "Captain Phillips" a tensely compelling dramatization of a harrowing modern pirate scenario.

"Captain Philips" is a realistic, suspenseful, and emotional portrayal of the true story 2009 hijacking of the U.S. cargo ship Maersk Alabama by Somali pirates. The story was slow to pull in my attention and it lulled at moments, but it chugged along and ultimately did its duty well. Visually impressive and raw cinematography add to the gritty and harsh realism of the situation Captain Phillips, his crew, and the pirates endured. Tom Hanks' performance was nothing short of quality, as usual, and the ending scenes were an emotional powerhouse. Simply riveting! It literally brought me to tears. The supporting cast were equally believable and captivating in their roles. I especially like the way the story gave an understanding perspective of the Somali pirates. 
These pirates were people were trying to make a living just like the rest of us. Their fish had been depleted by foreign commercial fishing ships and their options were running low concerning their survival. Captain Philips implored to Muse (the head pirate), "There must be something other than fishing and kidnapping people." Muses' sobering response of "Maybe in America" forces us to realize that despite our country's hardships, we are still so very lucky to be in such a place where we know there is no way we can starve. These men are so skinny, as they truly are, it is understandable they would resort to piracy. However, I have to agree with Phillips: there has to be something else you can do to thrive other than hurting other people, no matter where you live. 
The Somali pirates' greed eventually led to their downfall. They could have take the 30 thousand dollars and ran, but they wanted more by taking Phillips hostage. So it is difficult for me to fell much remorse about the fact that they in the end, they simply end up with their heads full of lead. Perhaps the only innocent casualty was the young pirate who did not know any better than to come along and do his job. "I didn't think something like this would happen," he cries.
This movie is very watchable, it is realistic, not overplayed, and the ending will have you locked in your seat. They could have ended the movie with the killing of the pirates, but that would not have done the story justice. I am so so glad they took the time to show the emotional aftermath of the traumatized Captain Phillips which in my opinion deliver the best scenes of the movie.

- 'Captain Philips' is a 2013 drama thriller from director Paul Greengrass (Bourne Trilogy) and inspired on actual events. The film was nominated six times at the last Academy Award Ceremony. Recommended by a friend, I was pleasantly surprised by the intensity of the movie. You literary sit on the edge of your seat as the brilliant Tom Hanks (Forrest Gump, Cloud Atlas) tries to keep his head cool during a hijacking. 

Leaving his family behind for several weeks to take command of a containership in Oman, captain Richard Philips (Hanks) must sail to the dangerous territory round the Horn of Africa. During one of the practice drills to prevent hijackers from entering, two little vessels show up on the radar. A group of young Somali criminals are approaching heavily armed. Captain Philips orders the crew to put the boat into full speed to outrun them. But the leader of the gang, Abduwali Muse, is not giving up that easily. He wants to hijack the containership because it is worth millions of American dollars. When Muse and three of his men get onboard, captain Philips faces the most fearful time of his life. Can he come to an agreement with the pirates so nobody gets hurt?

Look at me, look at me (well maybe you can't) but I am the pun captain now. Because I am going to hold you hostage with a plethora of puns in yet another film review voyage upon my pun-man ship. Please don't jump off!! OK, I am going to bring you my insight of the masterful movie "Captain Phillips". The film is based on the real life 2009 incident where cargo ship capitan Richard Phillips was taken hostage on a cargo lifeboat by four Somali pirates. Tom Hanks pitch-perfect starring performance as the title character was on board as one of the best acting efforts of the year. It's too bad the Academy rocked the boat when they left Hanks off the Best Actor Oscar nominee list. Newcomer Somalian actor Barkhad Abdi's freshman effort as the Somalian pirate leader Muse was a gem. Abdi's facial expressions alone were worthy of all the acting accolades his performance has received. Director Paul Greengrass has once again proved that the green is always richer on our side when he is orchestrating suspense action films based on true stories. Greengrass anchors "Captain Phillips" quite swiftly, just as he perfectly piloted "United 93". Billy Ray's screenplay was very compelling and included what probably is the movie catchphrase of the year "I'm the captain now". So whether you pirate this movie or not (recommending the latter of course), you should take a look at "Captain Phillips".

A Hollywood-produced, politically correct, big studio vehicle, helmed by a world-class action artisan Paul Greengrass, stars the most revered actor of his generation, Tom Hanks as the titular captain, whose screen image is a paragon of an orthodox ordinary Joe alike American hero, in this seafaring hijack inspired by a true event in 2009 at Somali waters. It is a retaliation of the vicious circle from the poverty-stricken to the hegemony which sardonically offers them the alms and simultaneously capitalizes on their natural resources and weaponry merchandizing, so it is not easy to hold a phlegmatic perspective to watch the man-made terror without deploring the sad truth how things have ended up like this, for sure we should inveigh against the piracy felony, all the same we should also see through the phenomena and ferret out the nitty-gritty which induces the atrocious tragedies. We have both parties to blame and need a soul-searching examination on our own conscience. 

Greengrass adopts an engaging procedure to re-enact the white-knuckle happening of how the ship is seized by four Somali pirates (leading by a scrawny Muse, played by the first-time actor, now Oscar-nominee Abdi), parallels the narrative from both sides, playing mind games and a hide-and-seek inside the vessel, this is the first half, culminated with the pirates take captain Phillips as the hostage in a lifeboat, floating back the Somali. Apparently from the hindsight, it is a preventable incident, considering it is a US cargo ship, no one on board is equipped with any firearms at all? From a gun frenzy country where campus shooting is rampant, it is quite implausible, but sometimes the truth is as simple as that, the pirates' boarding process is rough and ready, clearly the affluent corporate which owns the ship skimps on its defense system, although they are fully aware of the potential peril could happen anytime. Otherwise, there would be no big deal to defeat four sea marauders (one is barely a child) even they're equipped with AK-18.

Anyway, the second half, Captain Phillips is held captive within a lifeboat with the pirates on the billowy sea, since then, the film heavily hinges on Hank's performance to emanate the brewing desperation during the so-called "negotiation" between US rescue team (SEAL, frogmen are all standby) and the cornered pirates four. It is a precious platform to let Hanks finally have something extraordinary to offer, he completes it with consummate precision and sublimates the predictable fallout of the false hope. Unfortunately due to a crammed year with sterling candidates, Hanks is left out of the nomination list, quite an upsetting snub, but he plays a real person who lacks for a distinctive character except he is under an extreme situation, not showy enough is the detrimental disadvantage. Abdi is the MVP among the pirates four, not as irritable and impatient as the hackneyed short-fuse Najee (Ahmed), he is a human being with flesh and blood, he is the one captain Phillips can relate to under such circumstances, all diversities aside, basically they both work for their respective bosses and want to finish their jobs with minimal casualties. His bold final move can be interpreted as a smart judgment call, his American dream ironically fulfills in a different way, at least he can be plumb free of his ill-destined fate.

Yet another damn fine biopic from director Paul Greengrass. Assuming you already know of this harrowing true story there really shouldn't be any surprises, but the intensity of the performances coupled with the proficient camera work keep you in the moment at all times. There is the distinct air of patriotism to the whole thing, as you would expect, and there should be. Captain Phillips may not be as transcendent or powerful as United 93, but it represents the Hollywood treatment well.
